What is being talked about is the Quantum Vacuum. Defined as an absolute void. The start point is nothing, no particles, waves or anything else. Despite this nothingness observations from particle accelerators show that this has "potentialities" which can be expressed as Virtual Particles. These virtual particles can become actual particles but annihilate each other almost instantaneously. This produces a minute burst of energy which is observable as per the Casimir Effect. They are completely independent of Space-Time separation allowing for the Tunnel Effect allowing a particle to disappear from one point and reappear at another point instantaneously or even appear at two or more places simultaneously. An anti-particle has also been found to be equivalent to a normal particle travelling backwards in time.

As you have stated the question "What came before time?" is essentially nonsensical. However because virtual particles are independent of spacetime Quantum Fluctuation can act as primary cause. The Quantum Vacuum does not contain virtual particles, if it did it would not be a quantum vacuum. The virtual particles emerge from the quantum vacuum despite this. To attempt to use classical logic in the Quantum world is futile. Observation has peculiar effects in Quantum Mechanics hence Schodinger's Cat, this is due to the fact that observation involves the transfer of quanta. Quantum Foam is the "ripple effect" of spacetime at the smallest level. Unless you are claiming that spacetime itself is composed of particles your statement is nonsensical.

Beyond the Planck Level Spacetime becomes quantised and discontinuous, thus we observe the inability to observe beyond the planck level. This the point at which the search for the 'theory of everything' kicks in due to the problem of integrating gravity, inferring infinite infinities.

Within our universe Quantum fluctuations are limited by the Planck Constant to a minimum duration of 10-43 seconds. Energy released by a Quantum fluctuation is proportional to the speed of the particles and thus inversely to the length of time of their existence. The energy release of the Big Bang infers a Quantum Fluctuation with a duration of 10-160 seconds, obviously faster than could be allowed for in the constraints of spacetime thus must have come from nothing.
